title.children: Qantas is no stranger to turbulence, but it's flown headfirst into controversies it didn't see coming

title.children: Driver charged over crash that killed siblings in Sydney ‘extremely upset’ over deaths, court told

image.altText: Dutton walks through a crowd wearing Liberal blue shirts.

items.synopsis: A commitment by Liberal Party leader Peter Dutton to hold a second referendum on Indigenous recognition has been rubbished by one of the leading conservative Voice campaigners.

title.children: Dutton criticised by 'Liberals for Yes' group over pledge for second Indigenous recognition referendum

image.altText: A man looking at a destroyed vehicle near a road.

items.synopsis: Progress in Ukraine's counteroffensive has been slower than expected, but its forces are building momentum in the country's south, and could be just 15 kilometres away from a major prize.

title.children: Why Ukraine could be just 15km from forcing Putin to make an impossible choice

image.altText: A firefighter works at a site which was hit during Russia's drone attacks in Odesa.

image.altText: Morrison sits on the green bench in the back row of parliament with his arms crossed

items.synopsis: In years gone by, former prime ministers were often trusted confidants to their successors. Not so these days, when the trend has been for former leaders to make a swift exit from the parliament, writes Paul Strangio.

title.children: When PMs are booted from leadership, they typically opt to leave parliament. So why hasn't Scott Morrison?

items.synopsis: Roy Morgan says the level of distrust for corporate Australia has never been so high, writes Gareth Hutchens.

image.altText: A man shelters under a small stool from hail.

items.synopsis: From drought and bushfires to hail storms and flooding, El Niño's official declaration for the first time in eight years is likely to bring it all. Or maybe not. We look back at the impacts the major climate driver has brought to Australia in the past.

title.children: How might this year's potential El Niño compare to previous events?

image.altText: A blonde white man wears a pink shirt, while riding in the back of a pink car driven by a white blonde woman in a pink outfit.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Barbie becomes the year's highest-grossing film, Casey Donovan stranded at Burning Man. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New industrial relations legislation will be introduced to parliament today, which the government says will close loopholes that currently lead to unfair pay and conditions. Political reporter Evelyn Manfield explains what's being debated: This is the second tranche of the government's industrial relations reform. Under the change, the Fair Work Act would be amended to close a so-called loophole where an employer and employees have agreed through an enterprise agreement to a particular rate of pay, but then that pay is undercut when the employer brings in different workers through labour hire. The bill is also promising to introduce greater protections for gig economy workers and casuals, and increase penalties for wage theft. But business groups are opposing the changes, arguing they add complexity and will drive up costs. Political reporter Stephanie Borys was on News Breakfast earlier and said the bill will be debated for four weeks in the House of Representatives before it goes to the Senate where the government needs to find the numbers from the Greens and crossbench to get it through.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New industrial relations legislation to be introduced to parliament

children.content: New industrial relations legislation will be introduced to parliament today, which the government says will close loopholes that currently lead to unfair pay and conditions.

in the House of Representatives before it goes to the Senate where the government needs to
find the numbers from the Greens and crossbench
to get it through.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More wet weather is forecast in Nevada, where thousands of Burning Man festival attendees are being asked to shelter in place. North America correspondent Barbara Miller filed this report a little earlier. Further rain, some thunderstorms and gusty winds are forecast for Black Rock City - the site of the annual Burning Man festival. Tens of thousands of festival-goers are being asked not to leave because the roads are still too wet and muddy to officially open. Local authorities are investigating a death which occurred during the heavy rain. No further details have been provided. After postponing the burning of the huge wooden effigy called the Man, the event's signature event, organisers say they hope to go ahead with it later today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities investigating death at Burning Man

props.alt: People walk through the mud at Burning Man.

children.content: ( Trevor Hughes/USA Today Network via Reuters)
More wet weather is forecast in Nevada, where thousands of Burning Man festival attendees are being asked to shelter in place.
North America correspondent Barbara Miller filed this report a little earlier.
Further rain, some thunderstorms and gusty winds are forecast for Black Rock City - the site of the annual Burning Man festival.
Tens of thousands of festival-goers are being asked not to leave because the roads are still too wet and muddy to officially open.
Local authorities are investigating a death which occurred during the heavy rain. No further details have been provided.
After postponing the burning of the huge wooden effigy called the Man, the event's signature event, organisers say they hope to go ahead with it later today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jimmy Buffett died of a rare, aggressive skin cancer, according to a statement on his website. Buffett, 76, had Merkel cell cancer, according to the statement, which also noted the Margaritaville singer died at his home in Sag Harbor, New York, near the Hamptons. He had been fighting the cancer for four years while continuing to perform, the last time making a surprise appearance in Rhode Island in early July, the statement said. Merkel cell carcinoma, as it's known in medical literature, is very rare and tends to spread quickly, including to parts of the body beyond the skin, according to the federal National Cancer Institute and the Mayo Clinic. Risk factors include a lot of sun exposure, a weakened immune system, a history of other cancers, and being light-skinned and over 50.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jimmy Buffett died after a four-year fight with a rare form of skin cancer

children.content: (Brett Duke /The Times-Picayune/The New Orleans Advocate via AP)
Jimmy Buffett died of a rare, aggressive skin cancer, according to a statement on his website.
Buffett, 76, had Merkel cell cancer, according to the statement, which also noted the Margaritaville singer died at his home in Sag Harbor, New York, near the Hamptons.
He had been fighting the cancer for four years while continuing to perform, the last time making a surprise appearance in Rhode Island in early July, the statement said.

Merkel cell carcinoma, as it's known in medical literature, is very rare and tends to spread quickly, including to parts of the body beyond the skin, according to the federal National Cancer Institute and the Mayo Clinic.
Risk factors include a lot of sun exposure, a weakened immune system, a history of other cancers, and being light-skinned and over 50.
